abstracts.cdata!:
On January 26, 2004, the Inspection
            Panel (Panel) received a Request for Inspection (Request)
            related to the Indigenous and Community Biodiversity Project
            in Mexico, which, in accordance with the Resolution
            establishing the Inspection Panel (Resolution), the Panel
            notified the Executive Directors and the President of the
            Bank that it had received the Request, which constituted
            Registration of the Request, under the Panel's
            Operating Procedures. The Panel received Bank
            Management's Response to the Request on March 2, 2004
            (Management Response). This report  determines the
            eligibility of the Request, and makes a recommendation as to
            whether the Panel should investigate the matters alleged in
            the Request. The objective of the Project is to conserve
            high biodiversity areas in the states of Oaxaca, Michoacan,
            and Guerrero, by strengthening and promoting community
            conservation initiatives on communally-owned lands, building
            on their cultural values, and practices, developed in
            relationship to the resources in these areas. According to
            the Request, the Bank has violated its policies and
            procedures on project supervision and indigenous peoples,
            because it has proposed a restructuring of the Project
            without involving the State Committees. It alleges that the
            Bank has proposed modifying the Project so as "to
            divest the State Committees of their authority and vest the
            national coordinator with full powers.''
            Management states that "as of October 2003, discussions
            had not yet advanced to the stage of specific restructuring
            proposals to be considered by the State Committees,"
            adding it "will continue to involve systematic
            consultation with Project stakeholders."  The Panel
            observed that the Bank's supervision of the Project
            appears to have been inadequate in certain respects, and, an
            issue of broader concern to the Panel is the proposed
            restructuring of the Project, particularly given the
            Project's "demand-driven" nature. The Request
            and Management Response contain conflicting assertions, and
            interpretations about the issues, the facts, and compliance
            with Bank policies and procedures. Moreover, the Panel
            continues to be very concerned that a restructuring of the
            Project not be detrimental to the interests of the
            indigenous communities. In light of the foregoing, and in
            fairness to all the parties concerned, the Panel cannot take
            a position at this time on whether the Request merits an
            investigation, and awaits further developments.
